summary: Email chain between Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys and a federal prosecutor regarding logistics for the defense team to review physical and electronic evidence in the criminal case. The correspondence details negotiations over access to evidence stored at an FBI warehouse in the Bronx and at 500 Pearl Street courthouse, including highly confidential materials such as nude images seized from Jeffrey Epstein's devices.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from Cohen & Gresser LLP, coordinating evidence review logistics and planning to visit the FBI warehouse.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C., lead defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell corresponding with prosecutors about evidence access and procedural issues.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell copied on evidence review correspondence.

persons.name: Bobbi C Sternheim
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell copied on evidence review correspondence.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the criminal case, whose defense team is arranging for her to review evidence while in custody at MDC.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier whose residences were searched, and from whose devices the highly confidential images and other evidence were seized.

connections.description: Menninger is lead defense attorney representing Maxwell in the criminal case, as shown in her advocacy for Maxwell's evidence review rights.
Everdell is part of Maxwell's defense team, coordinating logistics for evidence review on her behalf.
Evidence being reviewed was seized from Epstein's residences and devices, relating to the joint investigation of both individuals.
Menninger is negotiating evidence access and procedural matters with the prosecuting AUSA representing the Southern District of New York.

events.title: Planned Bronx Warehouse Evidence Review
events.description: Defense team plans to visit FBI warehouse at 2350 Lafayette Ave, Bronx, to inspect and photograph evidence items excluded from transport to the courthouse.

events.title: Scheduled Evidence Review at 500 Pearl Street
events.description: Beginning of evidence review at the courthouse where Ghislaine Maxwell will be produced daily by Marshals, with review scheduled from 9:30am to 4:30pm.

events.title: FBI Searches of Epstein Residences
events.description: FBI conducted searches of Jeffrey Epstein's residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands, seizing electronic devices and physical evidence.

events.title: Production of Images and Videos
events.description: Government produced images and videos from Epstein's devices to defense, with cover letter noting highly confidential nude/partially nude images would be made available for review.

locations: 26 Federal Plaza, New York, NY (FBI office)
St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007 (U.S. Attorney's Office)
150 E. 10th Avenue, Denver, CO 80203 (Haddon, Morgan & Foreman law office)
keyFacts: The defense team sought to review all physical evidence, including approximately 2,100 previously undisclosed highly confidential electronic images and videos seized from Jeffrey Epstein's devices.
Evidence included nude/partially nude images categorized as 'Highly Confidential' under a protective order, with restrictions on photography and duplication.
Physical evidence seized included electronic devices, framed photos, plaster busts of female torsos, a stuffed dog, and shredded paper from FBI investigations in Florida and New York.
Prosecutors noted that some electronic evidence had metadata stripped, particularly for 'carved or deleted' images from Epstein's devices.
The correspondence reveals tension between defense demands for comprehensive evidence access and government concerns about logistics, security, and protective order compliance.
